Him, Dead, a Devil, but in Life a Saint.
In fine,
To make the Tories Grin, the Whigs to laugh,
We will conclude with Towzers Epitaph,

lg.head: VIZ.
lg.l: Hic jacet old Towzer with his Elder Guns,
VVho ſplit them, all by ramming Paper Puns
So hard into their Mouths, with ſtrong Intents
To guard the Pope, but blow up Parliaments;
But now he's Dead, his name will dye and rot,
Unleſs remembred like the Powder-Plot.
Our Priend hath here ſo mauld him Hip and Thigh,
That ſome do think, he'l never make Reply,
And if you like his Honeſt Gooſe-quill Blows,
As well in Verſe as keen Steeleto Proſe,
I ray thank him fort, and here we will now cloſe,
Gratias, Gratias, Gratias,

l.hi: And all clapt Hands with loud acclamations.

lg.l: BUt ſtay Our Lads, to you we will rehearſe
Before we part, an old right Roman Verſe,
VVhich may well ſerve, for to Conclude Our Play;
Look here, 'tis Ovid, which we read to Day,
In Nova fert animus, mutatas dicere formas, &c.
And now like him, in Our Poetick Feude,
If you will hear, to him we will Allude, viz,
A Tiber Gooſe is turn'd into a Kite,
A Ravens-croft is Romes grand Proſelyte,
Thats Turbulent, within his Magot Pate
Is turn'd Vulpone, in Our Church and State:
Brave Godfrey's Nat. is turn'd into a Jayle;
Pindarique Ridens, a true Roman Flaile;
Ben. Tooke's Ship is turn'd into a Lighter;
Jack Pudding he, is turned an old Sheep Biter,
The Tory Mountain's turn'd into a Mouſe,
Towzer's great Flea, is turn'd into a Louſe,
And though he skipt before, yet now muſt crawl,
And ſcratch his Noddle, at his own down-fall,
For ſending Ratio. to his Bedlam Cell,
VVhere he hath foil'd him, by that very ſpell,
VVherein he thought to cure his Frantick Brains,
Now Martins Ludgate, pay him for his Fains,
Or elſe pay Ratio, with your Hearty Thanks,
For theſe his Hocus, and new BEDLAM Pranks,
VVherein he hath (the Whigs will ſay no doubt)
In his new BEDLAM, found bold Towzer out,
VVe often ſee a ſpark much like a Louſe
In Magnitude doth ſometimes Burn a Houſe.
Towzer was he, who kindled firſt the ſpark,
And now his Houſe is Rent and Torn, and Dark,
He was the Man, who firſt began to Prate,
And for his Pains deſerves a broken Pate,
Theſe Lines will Live, when his ſhall Dye and Rot
And be to him an everlaſting Blot,
VVe wiſh him well, and always we will pray,
He may repent before his Judgment day,
For all his Follies, where he doth expoſe
True Loyal Subjects, to be Caeſars Foes,
If this ben't Madneſs, we have loſt Our Reaſon;
Some Men Write Non-ſence, and will have it Treaſon:
Theſe are the Bedlams, or we have no skill,
And Ignoramus of Our Makers VVill,
But yet we hope to ſee true Tories run,
In a ſhort time from Towzers Elder Gun;
VVho hath Bewitcht them ever ſince his Tone
Of Curſe ye Meroz, and his Forty One.

div.p: Schollars, Gratias, Gratias, Gratias, With loud acclamation. Saying,

l.hi: Vivat Rex, Vivat Rex, Vivat Rex,
Currat Lex, currat Lex, &c.
Laborat Grex, Laborat Grex, &c.

lg.l: Let Towzer Vex, Let Towzer Vex.

l.hi: Creſcit ſub Pondere Virtus

lg.l: ET
Soli Deo Gloria. Amen.
BUT ſtay a while the Tories firſt muſt come,
And take the Teſt, and then we ſhall have done;
Tories draw nigh, and take the Teſt once more,
Have we ſpoke Truth (or Treaſon) as before?

sp.speaker: Tories.
sp.p: Truth, Truth, Truth.

sp.speaker: Tantivys.
sp.l: Treaſon, Treaſon, Treaſon.
VVhat ails theſe Tories and Tantivy Eives,
Now at the laſt to contradict themſelves?
By which you plainly ſee with your own Eyes,
Some Tories can ſpeak Truth, though moſt tell Lyes.
The laſt are Towzers VVhelps, the firſt are thoſe
VVho now have fairly bit them by the Noſe,
Common-Prayer Whigs the firſt, the laſt are ſuch
VVho neither ſtay at home, nor go to Church,
But every Sunday having got the Spleen,
They take the Air to Viſit Doctor Green;
But ſince you are ſo high, Tantivys Pray
Tell us the Treaſon you have heard to Day.

sp.speaker: Tantivys.
sp.l: In ſaying, That his Name ſhall Dye and Rot
Unleſs remembred like the Powder-Plot;
If this be not, both flat and downright Treaſon,
You may Conclude, That we have loſt Our reaſon.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth,
sp.l: If you'l withdraw we'l put it to the Teſt,
Of theſe great Peers, their Judgments are the beſt.

sp.speaker: Tantivys.
sp.l: With all Our Hearts, provided that we may
But be aſſured, we ſhall have fair Play;
Dont queſtion that, theſe Peers they art not thoſe,
VVho are the Kingdoms, and the Churches Foes,
VVe all do know, that theſe are truly Loyal,
Experieuce teacheth, VVe have had the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Tantivys,
sp.l: The Lords conclude that you have loſt your Sences,
By drinking hard, and ſitting late with VVenches,
And by Your VVords which you affirm are Treaſon,
They do Conclude, that you have loſt Your reaſon;
And out as much as that true Roman Elf,
VVho is to prove that Godfrey Hang'd Himſelf:
For which attempt, to Newgate he was ſent
Among his BULLIES, there to keep his Lent;
And may you all, be ſent to him in Seaſon,
To cure the Itch of this your Purblind Treaſon.

p.hi: Now Gentlemen and Ladies, you are all moſt heartily welcome.
And all clap Hands with loud Acclamations.

div.head: POSTSCRIPT.
To the Tantivies, By T. T.

lg.l: AS our two Jeſuits, from the Starrs above,
Were ſtruck with Paleneſs, and dead drunk with Love.
From Cupid's Engine, call'd his Charming Dart,
With which he makes hot Loves often ſmart,
By means whereof, Our Royal Charles his Life
Was ſaſely guarded from ROME's inrag'd Knife,
Which do's appear like Lambs to vulgar ſight,
But inwardly are Ravening Wolves of Night.
So now likewiſe: If Towzer he ſhall rage
And bark at us, in every weekly Page,
To quench the Flames of our new Bedlam Play,
Which if he can, then VVe muſt run away:
And 'twould ſeem ſtrange, That Joan's old Elder Gun
Should make Tom Tell-troth, at the laſt, to Run;
VVe fear him not, Come let him do his worſt,
The more he barks, the more he will be curſt
By God himſelf, who never ſhoots at Rovers,
And will at length ſlay all right Roman Drovers,
VVe have a Diſtick alwayes holding true,
Though not yet heeded by your curſed Crew,
The Palm-tree grows the more preſt down,
And Croſſes prove the Churches Crown.
Repent in time, thank Tell-Truth for this hint,
And doe no more on him ſo look a-ſquint.
VVhich if you ſhould, he'l pay you home, be ſure,
Now you have put his jealous Pen in Ure,
By your old Hocus tricks, wherein you huff,
And light them up, Juſt like a Candle Snuff,
And ſo will end, or we have loſt our Aim,
And do deſerve, an everlaſting Blame
Be put upon us, by ſuch Fops as you,
VVho are the Tory and Tantivy Crew,
But We're the honeſt and true loyal Blew.
